questions.statement: Computer ethics is a set of acceptable behaviors for using a computer and the Internet.
questions.explanation: This is the definition of computer ethics as stated in the textbook.

questions.statement: The Internet can only be used for entertainment purposes.
questions.explanation: The Internet has many advantages including education, communication, e-commerce, abundant information, and entertainment.

questions.statement: Google Chrome is a search engine.
questions.explanation: Google Chrome is a web browser, not a search engine. Google is a search engine.

questions.statement: Social media platforms are used for interaction, content sharing, and collaboration.
questions.explanation: Social media refers to the online communication platform used for interaction, content sharing, and collaboration among users.

questions.statement: E-commerce means buying and selling of goods and services online.
questions.explanation: E-commerce enables buying and selling of goods and services online using the Internet.

questions.statement: Spam is a helpful email that provides useful information.
questions.explanation: Spam refers to unwanted, unsolicited, and useless e-mail that may carry advertisements or malware.

questions.statement: Internet addiction can negatively affect students' studies.
questions.explanation: Students who spend a lot of time on social media may waste useful time, which can negatively affect their studies.

questions.statement: Plagiarism is a serious offence that results in severe penalties.
questions.explanation: Plagiarism refers to using others' ideas without acknowledgment and is a serious offence with severe penalties.

questions.statement: Citation is the simplest technique to avoid plagiarism.
questions.explanation: Mentioning an acknowledgment of the source of used information (citation) is the simplest technique to avoid plagiarism.

questions.statement: Cyberbullying can only happen through email.
questions.explanation: Cyberbullying is an act using the Internet, digital technologies, or mobile phones - not just email.

questions.statement: Cyberbullying can cause developmental issues in children.
questions.explanation: Cyberbullying can be very stressful to the victim, especially children, and can cause several developmental issues.

questions.statement: A white hat hacker breaks into systems for the purpose of fixing flaws and improving security.
questions.explanation: A hacker (white hat hacker) breaks into a computer system for the purpose of fixing flaws and improving security with permission.

questions.statement: A cracker gains unauthorized access to computers to help people.
questions.explanation: A cracker (black hat hacker) gains unauthorized access for the purpose of stealing or corrupting data.

questions.statement: Keyloggers are programs that can read keystrokes to steal confidential information.
questions.explanation: Some programs can read keystrokes pressed by a user on a keyboard to steal confidential information. These are called Keyloggers.

questions.statement: A firewall is used to start fires in computers.
questions.explanation: A firewall is a network security program to keep a check on incoming and outgoing information.

questions.statement: Norton, MacAfee, and Kaspersky are examples of antivirus software.
questions.explanation: Norton, MacAfee, Kaspersky, Quick Heal are examples of antivirus programs mentioned in the textbook.

questions.statement: Phishing emails often promise prizes like lottery winnings to trick users.
questions.explanation: Phishing e-mails often promote gifts and lure users into revealing their private credentials.

questions.statement: Banks will often ask you to send your password by email.
questions.explanation: Banks will NEVER ask you to send your password or personal information by e-mail.

questions.statement: A secured website URL starts with https:// and shows a closed lock icon.
questions.explanation: Enter sensitive data only in secured websites that start with https:// and show a closed lock icon.

questions.statement: Vishing uses phone calls or voice messages to steal information.
questions.explanation: Vishing is a fraudulent act of using phone calls or voice messages pretending to be from a genuine company to steal confidential information.

questions.statement: E-mail bombing is sending requests to a resource many times more than it can handle.
questions.explanation: E-mail bombing is repeatedly sending the same e-mail to a particular address. Flooding is sending requests many times more than resources can handle.

questions.statement: A cookie is a malicious virus that destroys your computer.
questions.explanation: A cookie is a small piece of data that collects information of your online activity and reports it to the host for marketing purposes.

questions.statement: COPPA is a law created to protect the privacy of children under 13 years of age.
questions.explanation: The Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) is a law created to protect the privacy of children under 13 years of age.

questions.statement: Software piracy is legal if you share with friends.
questions.explanation: Software piracy is illegal copying of software without buying the license. You cannot give duplicate copies to your friends.

questions.statement: Copyright laws protect creative works such as books, movies, music, and software.
questions.explanation: Copyright laws typically protect creative works such as books, movies, music, paintings, photographs, and software.

questions.statement: A trademark is used to protect inventions.
questions.explanation: A trademark is used to identify and distinguish products. A patent is used to protect inventions.

questions.statement: A patent gives the creator the sole right to make, use, and sell an invention.
questions.explanation: A patent is a legal right that gives the creator of an invention the sole right to make, use, and sell that invention for a set period.

questions.statement: Cybercrime includes identity theft, forgery, defamation, and credit card account theft.
questions.explanation: Cybercrime includes identity theft, forgery, defamation, mischief, credit card account theft, etc.

questions.statement: Cybercrime is not punishable under any law.
questions.explanation: Cybercrime is punishable under IT Acts enacted in most countries with imprisonment and monetary fine.

questions.statement: Digital footprint is the information about a user that exists on the Internet from their online activity.
questions.explanation: The information about a particular user that exists on the Internet as a result of their online activity is called digital footprint.

questions.statement: Whatever you do online persists and establishes your online identity.
questions.explanation: Whatever you do online persists and establishes your online identity. Digital footprint can make or break your reputation.

questions.statement: A strong password should be at least 8 to 10 characters long.
questions.explanation: The length of the password should be at least 8 to 10 characters for it to be strong.

questions.statement: You should use your name or date of birth as a password because it's easy to remember.
questions.explanation: Do not use your name, family member's name, or date of birth as password, as these are easy to guess.

questions.statement: You should share your password with everyone so they can help you if you forget.
questions.explanation: Avoid writing down your password or sharing it with anyone. Only share with your parents.

questions.statement: You should check the 'Remember Password' option on public computers for convenience.
questions.explanation: Don't check the Remember Password or Stay Signed in option when working on public computers.

questions.statement: Spyware surveys your Internet behavior and copies your passwords without your knowledge.
questions.explanation: The spyware program surveys your Internet behavior and copies your passwords to use them for illegitimate purposes without your knowledge.

questions.statement: You should always download and install software without your parents' permission.
questions.explanation: Before you download and install a software, take permission of your parents.

questions.statement: Social networking sites have no minimum age requirement for membership.
questions.explanation: Many social networking sites prescribe a minimum age limit for membership. Do not acquire membership by faking your age.

questions.statement: Some companies search a candidate's online profile before giving them a job.
questions.explanation: Some companies search the candidate's online profile before giving the job. Similarly, some colleges give admission after searching the applicant's online profile.

questions.statement: Cyberterrorism is using the Internet to carry out violent activities causing loss of life.
questions.explanation: Cyberterrorism is an act of using the Internet to carry out violent activities causing loss of life or intimidation.

questions.statement: Internet is an integral part of modern education.
questions.explanation: Internet is an integral part of modern education. It is used extensively in conducting online classes, tests, and various examinations.

questions.statement: Mozilla Firefox is a search engine.
questions.explanation: Mozilla Firefox is a web browser, not a search engine.

questions.statement: Skype and Google Duo are used for video conferencing.
questions.explanation: Skype and Google Duo are video conferencing programs mentioned in the textbook.

questions.statement: X (formerly Twitter) is a social media platform.
questions.explanation: X (formerly known as Twitter) is one of the social media platforms mentioned in the textbook.

questions.statement: LinkedIn is primarily used for gaming.
questions.explanation: LinkedIn is a professional networking platform, not a gaming platform.

questions.statement: WhatsApp is a messaging application.
questions.explanation: WhatsApp is a messaging and communication application.

questions.statement: Wikipedia is a search engine.
questions.explanation: Wikipedia is an online encyclopedia (a social media platform for information sharing), not a search engine.

questions.statement: Malware spreads faster through the Internet because of many files and emails being shared.
questions.explanation: Malware spreads much faster through the Internet because of a large number of files and e-mails being shared on the Internet.

questions.statement: Kids can be exposed to adult content on the Internet, which is a disadvantage.
questions.explanation: The Internet can be misused by kids to access 'adult content' that is unsuitable for their viewing.

questions.statement: Careless sharing of personal information can lead to safety threats.
questions.explanation: Unknowingly kids can share too much personal information that could be stolen by miscreants, leading to threats to their safety.

questions.statement: According to computer ethics, you can spy on another person's data if they are your friend.
questions.explanation: One of the ethical rules is: Do not spy on another person's data, regardless of whether they are your friend or not.

questions.statement: It is ethical to claim ownership of someone else's work.
questions.explanation: Do not claim ownership on a work which is the output of someone else's work - this is unethical.

questions.statement: If you develop software to share online, you should think about its social impact.
questions.explanation: If you have developed a software and are willing to share it with others online, think about the social impact it can have.

questions.statement: Text, images, and information on the Internet are free to use without any acknowledgment.
questions.explanation: Text, images, and information on the Internet are often protected by copyright laws and require acknowledgment or permission.

questions.statement: Googling refers to searching the whereabouts of a person you meet online.
questions.explanation: Google yourself: Search the whereabouts of the person you meet online. This is called Googling.

questions.statement: If being cyberbullied, you should immediately fight back online.
questions.explanation: If being cyberbullied, you should Stop (take five minutes to calm down, do not get irritated), Block, and Tell your parents.

questions.statement: Cyberstalking is an act of using the Internet to stalk or harass a person.
questions.explanation: Cyberstalking is an act of using the Internet or any other electronic means to stalk or harass a person by labeling false accusations or defamation.

questions.statement: Cyber espionage is done with the permission of the information holder.
questions.explanation: Cyber spying or cyber espionage is an act of obtaining secrets without the permission and knowledge of the holder of the information.

questions.statement: Hackers need written permission from computer owners to hack into the system legally.
questions.explanation: Hackers should have written permission from computer or network owners to hack into the system.

questions.statement: Older versions of operating systems are safer than newer versions.
questions.explanation: Older versions may have loopholes that could be easily misused. The latest updates are upgraded to handle latest security challenges.

questions.statement: Adware places advertisements in your browser and slows down your computer.
questions.explanation: An adware program places advertisements in your browser and allows pop-ups. This will slow down your computer.

questions.statement: You should always click on links in emails claiming you won a lottery.
questions.explanation: Phishing emails often promote prizes like lottery winnings. Never click on such links or provide personal information.

questions.statement: Clickjacking is a phishing technique where users are tricked into clicking malicious items.
questions.explanation: Clickjacking is a type of phishing technique in which a user is tricked into clicking on an item that appears to be something useful but acts maliciously.

questions.statement: E-mail spoofing sends emails that appear to originate from one source but are sent from another.
questions.explanation: E-mail spoofing: Sending e-mail that appears to have originated from one source when it was actually sent from another source.

questions.statement: Flooding results in denial of service to authorized users.
questions.explanation: Flooding: Sending requests to a computer resource many times more than it can handle, resulting in denial of access to service to authorized users.

questions.statement: You should enter your email address at any website without checking its reliability.
questions.explanation: Do not enter your e-mail address at unreliable websites. This can lead to spam.

questions.statement: A person has no right to determine what information about them is collected online.
questions.explanation: A person has the right to determine what sort of information about him/her is collected and how that information is used.

questions.statement: You can set privacy level in social media websites to control shared information.
questions.explanation: You can set the privacy level in social media websites. These settings provide security levels such as share everything, share with friends, etc.

questions.statement: According to COPPA, websites can collect children's information without parental consent.
questions.explanation: According to COPPA, a website operator should seek verification of information of children from their parent or guardian.

questions.statement: When you buy original software, you can install it on unlimited computers.
questions.explanation: You have the right to use the software on a single or multiple computers, as per your license. You cannot install copies on extra computers.

questions.statement: Using illegal CDs from friends containing music or games is a form of software piracy.
questions.explanation: Do not use illegal CDs given to you by your friends containing your favorite music or games. This is software piracy.

questions.statement: Intellectual Property Rights protect the interests of creators over their creations.
questions.explanation: Intellectual Property Rights are legal property rights of the creator(s) over creations of their mind. These rights protect the interests of the creators/owners.

questions.statement: Trade secrets are public information that anyone can use.
questions.explanation: A trade secret is a non-public information concerning the commercial practices or secrets owned by a business owner. Public disclosure may be illegal.

questions.statement: Industrial design right protects the appearance and design of objects.
questions.explanation: An industrial design right is a legal right to identify and distinguish industrial objects by way of their appearance, style, or design.

questions.statement: Cyber trafficking may deal in drugs, weapons, and even humans.
questions.explanation: Cyber trafficking is an act of crime conducted on and propagated through the Internet. It may deal in drugs, weapons, other contrabands, and even humans.

questions.statement: Cybercrime can result in imprisonment and heavy monetary fine.
questions.explanation: A cybercrime is punishable under IT Acts enacted in most of the countries. You will be punished with imprisonment and heavy monetary fine if found guilty.

questions.statement: You should share personal information online without your parent's permission.
questions.explanation: Do not share your personal information without your parent's permission.

questions.statement: On public computers, you should logout properly after use.
questions.explanation: If you are working on a public computer, make sure you logout properly.

questions.statement: You can meet online friends without telling your parents.
questions.explanation: Don't agree to meet an online friend without your parent's permission.

questions.statement: If you feel uncomfortable with an online message, you should tell your parents or teacher.
questions.explanation: Don't send or respond to any message that makes you feel uncomfortable. Talk to your parents or teacher about it.

questions.statement: You can acquire social media membership by faking your age.
questions.explanation: Many social networking sites prescribe a minimum age limit for membership. Do not acquire the membership by faking your age.

questions.statement: When using online information in projects, you must acknowledge the source.
questions.explanation: If you use online information in your assignments/projects, make sure you acknowledge the source of information.

questions.statement: Consecutive letters and numbers like 'abcd' or '1234' make strong passwords.
questions.explanation: Consecutive letters of alphabets and numbers should be avoided as they are easy to guess.

questions.statement: You should create a new unused password when changing your password.
questions.explanation: When you change your password, create a new (unused) one every time.

questions.statement: It's safe to type your password while someone is looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Avoid typing your password while someone is looking over your shoulder, or when it is someone else's computer.

questions.statement: Digital footprint can affect your chances of getting a job or college admission.
questions.explanation: Some companies search the candidate's online profile before giving the job. Some colleges give admission after searching the applicant's online profile.

questions.statement: You should use a fake identity to establish your online presence.
questions.explanation: To establish the online identity, use your real name. Do not hide yourself with fake identity.

questions.statement: Social media lets the world hear your voice, so always stand by your words.
questions.explanation: Social media lets the world hear your voice in conversation that matters to you. Always stand by your words.

questions.statement: Before opening an email attachment from unknown sender, you should take permission from parents.
questions.explanation: Before you open an e-mail attachment from an unknown sender, take permission of your parents.

questions.statement: It is safe to buy things online without your parent's permission.
questions.explanation: Don't buy anything without your parent's permission.
